content.definition: A synthetic conduit used as an arterial or venous substitute when autologous vein is unavailable, unsuitable, or in anatomic locations where synthetic material is preferred. Major types include expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE/Gore-Tex) and woven/knitted polyester (Dacron). Selection depends on location, size match, infection risk, and required porosity.

characteristics: ePTFE: microporous, requires minimal preclotting, good handling
Knitted Dacron: most porous, requires preclotting, good compliance
Woven Dacron: least porous, no preclotting, rigid
Ring-reinforced: kink resistance at flexion points

clinical_pearls: Vein patency exceeds prosthetic especially below knee
Rifampin soaking may reduce infection risk
Miller cuff or Taylor patch may improve distal anastomosis patency

learning_objectives: Differentiate ePTFE and Dacron graft properties
Select appropriate graft for anatomic location
Understand techniques to improve prosthetic patency

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
